questions.text: A 65 year old male presented to OPD with complaints of hip pain, hearing loss of one side , fatigue, weakness, loss of appetite , abdominal pain and constipation . On examination frontal bossing was present. X ray examination revealed the following finding. Serum investigations revealed normal serum calcium, phosphate and PTH A diagnosis of Paget's disease was suspected, and the patient was started on Bisphosphonates. Which of the following statements is NOT true with respect to this diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Pagets is the disease of excessive bone formation, and the pathology is due to abnormal bone formation which is excessive and thick

options.label: B
options.text: The histopathology of the affected lesion reveals mosaic pattern

options.label: C
options.text: The subcutaneous injectable form of salmon calcitonin is approved for the treatment of paget's disease

options.label: D
options.text: Paget's disease is a quantitative defect of bone formation

questions.correct_answer: D. Paget's disease is a quantitative defect of bone formation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paget's disease is a quantitative defect of bone formation Paget disease is a localized disorder of bone remodeling that typically begins with excessive bone resorption followed by an increase in bone formation. This osteoclastic overactivity followed by compensatory osteoblastic activity leads to a structurally disorganized mosaic of bone (woven bone) (OPTION B), which is mechanically weaker, larger, less compact, more vascular, and more susceptible to fracture than normal adult lamellar bone . Symptomatology of paget’s: Bone pain (the most common symptom) Secondary osteoarthritis (when Paget disease occurs around a joint) Bony deformity (most commonly bowing of an extremity) Excessive warmth (due to hypervascularity) Neurologic complications (caused by the compression of neural tissues) Diagnosis : The diagnosis may be suggested on clinical examination by the presence of an enlarged skull with frontal bossing, bowing of an extremity, or short stature with simian posturing.

Highyeild:

Paget's disease is usually diagnosed from radiologic and biochemical abnormalities. Skull radiographs (image given in question) reveal regions of "cotton wool," or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic areas, and enlargement and sclerosis of a portion or all of one or more skull bones. The subcutaneous injectable form of salmon calcitonin is approved for the treatment of Paget's disease but is rarely used due to its low potency and should be reserved for patients who either do not tolerate bisphosphonates or have a contraindication to their use. (OPTION C).

Illustration of some genetic mutations that alter calcium metabolism by effects on the parathyroid cell or target cells of parathyroid hormone (PTH) action. Alterations in PTH production by the parathyroid cell can be caused by changes in the response to extracellular fluid calcium (Ca) that are detected by the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR). Furthermore, PTH (or PTH-related peptide [PTHrP]) can show altered efficacy in target cells such as in proximal tubular cells, by altered function of its receptor (PTH/PTHrP receptor) or the signal transduction proteins, G proteins such as G,a that is linked to adenylate cyclase (AC), the enzyme responsible for producing cyclic AMP (CAMP) (also illustrated are Gaq/Ga11, which activate an alternate pathway of receptor signal transmission involving the generation of inositol triphosphate [IP] or diacylglycerol [DAG]). Heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the CaSR cause familial benign hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FBHH) and homozygous mutations (both alleles mutated) and neonatal severe hyperparathyroidism (NSHPT); heterozygous gain-of-function causes autosomal dominant hypercalciuric hypocalcemia (ADHH). Other defects in parathyroid cell function that occur at the level of gene regulation (oncogenes or tumor-suppressor genes) or transcription factors are discussed in the text. Blomstrand's lethal chondrodysplasia is due to homozygous or compound heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the PTH/PTHrP receptor, a neonatally lethal disorder, while pseudohypoparathyroidism involves inactivation at the level of the G proteins, specifically mutations that eliminate or reduce Ga activity in the kidney (see text for details). Acrodysostosis can occur with (mutant regulatory subunit of PKA) or without hormonal resistance (mutant PDE4D or PDE3A). Jansen's metaphyseal chondrodysplasia and McCune-Albright syndrome represent gain-of-function mutations in the PTH/PTHrP receptor and G,a protein, respectively.

In addition, he reports recent hemoptysis and the onset of hoarseness. He also has had unintentional 10-kg (22 lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has a history of emphysema. A chest X-ray reveals a 6-cm hilar mass on the right. Laboratory studies show serum calcium 12 mg/dL (normal 8. 5-10. 5 mg/dL). Which of the following are mechanisms of hypercalcemia operative in this patient? 1. PTHrP associated bone resorption causing hyper Ca 2. Direct marrow invasion and secretion of lymphokines which promote bone resorption 3. Increased blood level of 1, 25 dihydroxy vit D produced by abnormal lymphocytes. Select the correct answer form the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2 and 3 are correct Key words - Dysphagia to solid = outside pressure to esophagus/ abnormal growth in esophagus Dysphagia to only liquid = obstruction due to spasm of esophagus and can be overcome by weighed solid food but not by lighter liquids, e. g. GERD] Hemoptysis = lung or respiratory tract problem = reason of dysphagia can be abnormal growth of lung tissue. Weight loss = towards cancer Hilar mass = cancer suspect Hypercalcemia = can be squamous cell cancer of the Lung.

Extraedge:

Mechanism of hyper Ca - Many solid tumors associated with hypercalcemia, particularly squamous cell and renal tumors, produce and secrete PTHrP that causes increased bone resorption and mediate the hypercalcemia through systemic actions on the skeleton. Direct bone marrow invasion occurs with hematologic malignancies such as leukemia, lymphoma, and multiple myeloma. In some lymphomas, there is a third mechanism, caused by an increased blood level of 1, 25(OH)2 D, produced by the abnormal lymphocytes.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a method of calculating estimated value of albumin adjusted calcium
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a method of calculating estimated value of albumin adjusted calcium Concept of adjusted calcium level = With change in serum albumin level ( e. g. in nephrotic syndrome) , total calcium concentration of blood also changes . Total calcium decreases with decrease in serum albumin. But this decrease in calcium is from calcium bound to albumin , and not from serum free calcium. Therefore serum free calcium is normal despite decreased value of serum total calcium. To predict this error in advance, we use ‘corrected/adjusted calcium’
